title: Drill: Basic Power Rule
description: Evaluate: $\int 4x^3 \, dx$
hints: Use the power rule: $\int x^n \, dx = \frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} + C$.
solution: $\int 4x^3 \, dx = 4 \cdot \frac{x^4}{4} + C = x^4 + C$

title: Drill: Exponential Integration
description: Evaluate: $\int 3e^x \, dx$
solution: $\int 3e^x \, dx = 3e^x + C$

title: Drill: Trigonometric Integration
description: Evaluate: $\int \cos x \, dx$
solution: $\int \cos x \, dx = \sin x + C$

title: Drill: Simple U-Substitution
description: Evaluate: $\int 2x(x^2 + 1)^3 \, dx$
solution: Let $u = x^2 + 1$, then $du = 2x \, dx$. So $\int 2x(x^2 + 1)^3 \, dx = \int u^3 \, du = \frac{u^4}{4} + C = \frac{(x^2 + 1)^4}{4} + C$

title: Polynomial Integration
description:
Evaluate the following integrals:

(a) $\int (3x^2 - 2x + 5) \, dx$

(b) $\int (x^3 - 4x^2 + x - 7) \, dx$

(c) $\int \frac{x^4 + 2x^2 - 1}{x} \, dx$
hints: Integrate each term separately using the power rule.
For (c), simplify by dividing each term by x first.
Don't forget the constant of integration!

title: Basic U-Substitution
description:
Evaluate the following using u-substitution:

(a) $\int x\sqrt{x^2 + 1} \, dx$

(b) $\int \frac{x}{x^2 + 1} \, dx$

(c) $\int x^2(x^3 - 5)^{10} \, dx$
hints: For (b), note that the numerator is related to the derivative of the denominator.
solution:
(a) Let $u = x^2 + 1$, then $du = 2x \, dx$, so $x \, dx = \frac{1}{2}du$.
$\int x\sqrt{x^2 + 1} \, dx = \int \sqrt{u} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{2u^{3/2}}{3} + C = \frac{(x^2 + 1)^{3/2}}{3} + C$

(b) Let $u = x^2 + 1$, then $du = 2x \, dx$, so $x \, dx = \frac{1}{2}du$.
$\int \frac{x}{x^2 + 1} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{u} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du = \frac{1}{2}\ln|u| + C = \frac{1}{2}\ln(x^2 + 1) + C$

(c) Let $u = x^3 - 5$, then $du = 3x^2 \, dx$, so $x^2 \, dx = \frac{1}{3}du$.
$\int x^2(x^3 - 5)^{10} \, dx = \int u^{10} \cdot \frac{1}{3} \, du = \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{u^{11}}{11} + C = \frac{(x^3 - 5)^{11}}{33} + C$

title: Trigonometric Integrals
description:
Evaluate:

(a) $\int \sin(3x) \, dx$

(b) $\int \sec^2(2x) \, dx$

(c) $\int x \cos(x^2) \, dx$
hints: For (a) and (b), use substitution with $u$ as the argument of the trig function.
Remember basic trig antiderivatives: $\int \sin u \, du = -\cos u + C$, $\int \sec^2 u \, du = \tan u + C$.
solution:
(a) Let $u = 3x$, then $du = 3 \, dx$, so $dx = \frac{1}{3}du$.
$\int \sin(3x) \, dx = \int \sin u \cdot \frac{1}{3} \, du = -\frac{1}{3}\cos u + C = -\frac{1}{3}\cos(3x) + C$

(b) Let $u = 2x$, then $du = 2 \, dx$, so $dx = \frac{1}{2}du$.
$\int \sec^2(2x) \, dx = \int \sec^2 u \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du = \frac{1}{2}\tan u + C = \frac{1}{2}\tan(2x) + C$

(c) Let $u = x^2$, then $du = 2x \, dx$, so $x \, dx = \frac{1}{2}du$.
$\int x \cos(x^2) \, dx = \int \cos u \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du = \frac{1}{2}\sin u + C = \frac{1}{2}\sin(x^2) + C$

title: Exponential and Logarithmic
description:
Evaluate:

(a) $\int 2^x \, dx$

(b) $\int \frac{1}{x \ln x} \, dx$

(c) $\int e^{3x+2} \, dx$
hints: For (a), use the formula $\int a^x \, dx = \frac{a^x}{\ln a} + C$.
solution:
(a) $\int 2^x \, dx = \frac{2^x}{\ln 2} + C$

(b) Let $u = \ln x$, then $du = \frac{1}{x} \, dx$.
$\int \frac{1}{x \ln x} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{u} \, du = \ln|u| + C = \ln|\ln x| + C$

(c) Let $u = 3x + 2$, then $du = 3 \, dx$, so $dx = \frac{1}{3}du$.
$\int e^{3x+2} \, dx = \int e^u \cdot \frac{1}{3} \, du = \frac{1}{3}e^u + C = \frac{1}{3}e^{3x+2} + C$

title: Mixed Practice
description:
Evaluate:

(a) $\int (5x^4 - 3\sqrt{x} + \frac{2}{x^2}) \, dx$

(b) $\int (e^x + \sin x) \, dx$

(c) $\int \frac{x^3 + x}{x^2} \, dx$
hints: Rewrite radicals and fractions as powers of x.

title: Chain Rule Reversals
description:
Evaluate:

(a) $\int \frac{e^{\sqrt{x}}}{\sqrt{x}} \, dx$

(b) $\int \tan x \, dx$ (Hint: $\tan x = \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}$)

(c) $\int \frac{\sec^2 x}{\tan x} \, dx$
hints: For (b), rewrite and use substitution $u = \cos x$.
solution:
(a) Let $u = \sqrt{x} = x^{1/2}$, then $du = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}} \, dx$, so $\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} \, dx = 2 \, du$.
$\int \frac{e^{\sqrt{x}}}{\sqrt{x}} \, dx = \int e^u \cdot 2 \, du = 2e^u + C = 2e^{\sqrt{x}} + C$

(b) $\int \tan x \, dx = \int \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} \, dx$. Let $u = \cos x$, then $du = -\sin x \, dx$.
$\int \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} \, dx = \int \frac{-1}{u} \, du = -\ln|u| + C = -\ln|\cos x| + C = \ln|\sec x| + C$

(c) Let $u = \tan x$, then $du = \sec^2 x \, dx$.
$\int \frac{\sec^2 x}{\tan x} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{u} \, du = \ln|u| + C = \ln|\tan x| + C$

title: Initial Value Problems
description:
Solve the following initial value problems:

(a) $f'(x) = 3x^2 - 2x$, $f(1) = 5$

(b) $\frac{dy}{dx} = e^x + \sin x$, $y(0) = 3$

(c) $g'(t) = \frac{1}{t}$, $g(1) = 2$
hints: Then use the initial condition to find the constant C.
Substitute the given point into your antiderivative.
solution:
(a) $f(x) = \int (3x^2 - 2x) \, dx = x^3 - x^2 + C$
Use $f(1) = 5$: $1^3 - 1^2 + C = 5$, so $C = 5$.
Therefore, $f(x) = x^3 - x^2 + 5$

(b) $y = \int (e^x + \sin x) \, dx = e^x - \cos x + C$
Use $y(0) = 3$: $e^0 - \cos 0 + C = 3$, so $1 - 1 + C = 3$, thus $C = 3$.
Therefore, $y = e^x - \cos x + 3$

(c) $g(t) = \int \frac{1}{t} \, dt = \ln|t| + C$
Use $g(1) = 2$: $\ln 1 + C = 2$, so $C = 2$.
Therefore, $g(t) = \ln|t| + 2$

title: Advanced Substitution
description:
Evaluate:

(a) $\int \frac{\ln x}{x} \, dx$

(b) $\int x e^{x^2} \, dx$

(c) $\int \frac{\sin(\ln x)}{x} \, dx$
solution:
(a) Let $u = \ln x$, then $du = \frac{1}{x} \, dx$.
$\int \frac{\ln x}{x} \, dx = \int u \, du = \frac{u^2}{2} + C = \frac{(\ln x)^2}{2} + C$

(b) Let $u = x^2$, then $du = 2x \, dx$, so $x \, dx = \frac{1}{2}du$.
$\int x e^{x^2} \, dx = \int e^u \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du = \frac{1}{2}e^u + C = \frac{1}{2}e^{x^2} + C$

(c) Let $u = \ln x$, then $du = \frac{1}{x} \, dx$.
$\int \frac{\sin(\ln x)}{x} \, dx = \int \sin u \, du = -\cos u + C = -\cos(\ln x) + C$

title: Completing the Square
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{1}{x^2 + 6x + 13} \, dx$
hints: Complete the square in the denominator: $x^2 + 6x + 13 = (x+3)^2 + 4$.
solution:
Complete the square: $x^2 + 6x + 13 = (x^2 + 6x + 9) + 4 = (x+3)^2 + 4$

Let $u = x + 3$, then $du = dx$.

$\int \frac{1}{x^2 + 6x + 13} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{u^2 + 4} \, du = \int \frac{1}{u^2 + 2^2} \, du$

Using the formula with $a = 2$:
$= \frac{1}{2}\arctan\left(\frac{u}{2}\right) + C = \frac{1}{2}\arctan\left(\frac{x+3}{2}\right) + C$

title: Antiderivatives with Absolute Values
description: Find the antiderivative: $\int \frac{2x + 3}{x^2 + 3x + 1} \, dx$
hints: Notice that the numerator is related to the derivative of the denominator.
solution:
Notice that if $u = x^2 + 3x + 1$, then $du = (2x + 3) \, dx$.

The numerator is exactly the derivative of the denominator!

$\int \frac{2x + 3}{x^2 + 3x + 1} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{u} \, du = \ln|u| + C = \ln|x^2 + 3x + 1| + C$

title: Algebraic Manipulation
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{x + 1}{\sqrt{x}} \, dx$
hints: Rewrite by splitting the fraction and converting to powers.
solution:
Rewrite the integrand:
$\frac{x + 1}{\sqrt{x}} = \frac{x}{\sqrt{x}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} = \frac{x}{x^{1/2}} + \frac{1}{x^{1/2}} = x^{1/2} + x^{-1/2}$

Now integrate:
$\int (x^{1/2} + x^{-1/2}) \, dx = \frac{x^{3/2}}{3/2} + \frac{x^{1/2}}{1/2} + C = \frac{2x^{3/2}}{3} + 2x^{1/2} + C$

Or: $= \frac{2\sqrt{x^3}}{3} + 2\sqrt{x} + C$

title: Challenge: Multiple Techniques
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{e^{2x}}{e^{2x} + 1} \, dx$
solution:
Let $u = e^{2x} + 1$, then $du = 2e^{2x} \, dx$, so $e^{2x} \, dx = \frac{1}{2}du$.

Also note that $e^{2x} = u - 1$.

$\int \frac{e^{2x}}{e^{2x} + 1} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{u} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \, du = \frac{1}{2}\ln|u| + C$

$= \frac{1}{2}\ln|e^{2x} + 1| + C = \frac{1}{2}\ln(e^{2x} + 1) + C$ (absolute value not needed since $e^{2x} + 1 > 0$)

title: Drill: Basic Definite Integral
description: Evaluate: $\int_0^2 x \, dx$
hints: Use the Fundamental Theorem: find the antiderivative and evaluate at the limits.

title: Drill: FTC Part 1
description: If $F(x) = \int_0^x t^2 \, dt$, find $F'(x)$.
hints: By FTC Part 1, the derivative of an integral is the integrand.
solution: By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus Part 1: $F'(x) = x^2$

title: Drill: Constant Integration
description: Evaluate: $\int_1^4 5 \, dx$
hints: The integral of a constant c is cx.

title: Drill: Negative Area
description: What is $\int_2^0 x \, dx$?
hints: Reversing the limits changes the sign.
solution: $\int_2^0 x \, dx = -\int_0^2 x \, dx = -\left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^2 = -2$

title: Definite Integrals with FTC
description:
Evaluate:

(a) $\int_1^3 (2x - 1) \, dx$

(b) $\int_0^{\pi/2} \sin x \, dx$

(c) $\int_1^e \frac{1}{x} \, dx$
hints: Find the antiderivative, then evaluate at the bounds.

title: FTC Part 1 Applications
description:
Find the derivative:

(a) $\frac{d}{dx}\int_0^x (t^2 + 1) \, dt$

(b) $\frac{d}{dx}\int_1^{x^2} \sin t \, dt$

(c) $\frac{d}{dx}\int_x^2 e^t \, dt$
hints: For (b), use chain rule with FTC Part 1.
solution:
(a) By FTC Part 1: $\frac{d}{dx}\int_0^x (t^2 + 1) \, dt = x^2 + 1$

(b) Let $u = x^2$. By FTC and chain rule: $\frac{d}{dx}\int_1^{x^2} \sin t \, dt = \sin(x^2) \cdot 2x$

(c) $\int_x^2 e^t \, dt = -\int_2^x e^t \, dt$, so $\frac{d}{dx}\int_x^2 e^t \, dt = -e^x$

title: Substitution in Definite Integrals
description: Evaluate $\int_0^1 2x(x^2 + 1)^2 \, dx$
hints: Don't forget to change the limits of integration!

title: Average Value
description: Find the average value of $f(x) = x^2$ on the interval $[0, 3]$.
solution:
Average value $= \frac{1}{3-0}\int_0^3 x^2 \, dx = \frac{1}{3}\left[\frac{x^3}{3}\right]_0^3$
$= \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{27}{3} = \frac{1}{3} \cdot 9 = 3$

title: Properties of Integrals
hints: Use linearity: $\int [af(x) + bg(x)] \, dx = a\int f(x) \, dx + b\int g(x) \, dx$.

title: Symmetric Functions
description:
Evaluate:

(a) $\int_{-2}^2 x^3 \, dx$

(b) $\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \cos x \, dx$
hints: Odd functions integrate to 0 over symmetric intervals.
Even functions: $\int_{-a}^a f(x) \, dx = 2\int_0^a f(x) \, dx$.
solution:
(a) $x^3$ is an odd function, so $\int_{-2}^2 x^3 \, dx = 0$

(b) $\cos x$ is an even function, so $\int_{-\pi}^{\pi} \cos x \, dx = 2\int_0^{\pi} \cos x \, dx = 2[\sin x]_0^{\pi} = 2(0 - 0) = 0$

title: Area and Sign
description: Compute $\int_{-1}^1 x \, dx$ and explain its geometric meaning.
solution:
$\int_{-1}^1 x \, dx = \left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_{-1}^1 = \frac{1}{2} - \frac{1}{2} = 0$

Geometrically: the line $y = x$ creates a triangle below the x-axis from -1 to 0 (area = -1/2) and above from 0 to 1 (area = +1/2). The signed areas cancel, giving 0.

title: Exponential Definite Integrals
description: Evaluate $\int_0^{\ln 2} e^x \, dx$

title: Substitution with Trig
description: Evaluate $\int_0^{\pi/4} \tan x \sec^2 x \, dx$
solution:
Let $u = \tan x$, then $du = \sec^2 x \, dx$.
When $x = 0$: $u = 0$
When $x = \pi/4$: $u = 1$

$\int_0^{\pi/4} \tan x \sec^2 x \, dx = \int_0^1 u \, du = \left[\frac{u^2}{2}\right]_0^1 = \frac{1}{2}$

title: Splitting Intervals
description: If $\int_0^5 f(x) \, dx = 12$ and $\int_5^8 f(x) \, dx = 7$, find $\int_0^8 f(x) \, dx$.
solution:
By the additivity property:
$\int_0^8 f(x) \, dx = \int_0^5 f(x) \, dx + \int_5^8 f(x) \, dx = 12 + 7 = 19$

title: Area Under Curve
description: Find the exact area under the curve $y = \sin x$ from $x = 0$ to $x = \pi$.

title: Challenge: Complex Substitution
description: Evaluate $\int_1^4 \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}} \, dx$ using substitution.
solution:
Let $u = \sqrt{x}$, so $x = u^2$ and $dx = 2u \, du$.
When $x = 1$: $u = 1$
When $x = 4$: $u = 2$

$\int_1^4 \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}} \, dx = \int_1^2 \frac{1}{2u} \cdot 2u \, du = \int_1^2 1 \, du = [u]_1^2 = 2 - 1 = 1$

Alternative: $\int_1^4 \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}} \, dx = \int_1^4 \frac{1}{2}x^{-1/2} \, dx = \frac{1}{2}\left[\frac{x^{1/2}}{1/2}\right]_1^4 = [\sqrt{x}]_1^4 = 2 - 1 = 1$

title: Drill: Integration by Parts Formula
description: State the integration by parts formula.
hints: It comes from the product rule.
solution: $\int u \, dv = uv - \int v \, du$

title: Drill: Basic Integration by Parts
description: Evaluate: $\int x e^x \, dx$
solution: Let $u = x$, $dv = e^x \, dx$. Then $du = dx$, $v = e^x$.\n\n$\int x e^x \, dx = xe^x - \int e^x \, dx = xe^x - e^x + C = e^x(x - 1) + C$

title: Drill: Trig Substitution Pattern
description: For $\sqrt{a^2 - x^2}$, which substitution should you use?
hints: Think about the Pythagorean identity with sine.
solution: Use $x = a \sin \theta$, which gives $\sqrt{a^2 - x^2} = a \cos \theta$.

title: Drill: Partial Fractions Setup
description: Write the partial fraction decomposition form for $\frac{1}{(x-1)(x+2)}$.
hints: Each distinct linear factor gets its own term.

title: Integration by Parts Practice
description:
Evaluate:

(a) $\int x \sin x \, dx$

(b) $\int x^2 e^x \, dx$
hints: For (b), you may need to use by parts twice.
solution:
(a) Let $u = x$, $dv = \sin x \, dx$. Then $du = dx$, $v = -\cos x$.
$\int x \sin x \, dx = -x\cos x - \int (-\cos x) \, dx = -x\cos x + \sin x + C$

(b) First: Let $u = x^2$, $dv = e^x \, dx$. Then $du = 2x \, dx$, $v = e^x$.
$\int x^2 e^x \, dx = x^2 e^x - 2\int x e^x \, dx$

Second: For $\int x e^x \, dx$, let $u = x$, $dv = e^x \, dx$. Then $du = dx$, $v = e^x$.
$\int x e^x \, dx = xe^x - e^x + C$

Combining: $\int x^2 e^x \, dx = x^2 e^x - 2(xe^x - e^x) + C = e^x(x^2 - 2x + 2) + C$

title: Logarithmic Integration
description: Evaluate $\int \ln x \, dx$
hints: Use integration by parts with $u = \ln x$, $dv = dx$.
solution: Let $u = \ln x$, $dv = dx$. Then $du = \frac{1}{x} \, dx$, $v = x$.\n\n$\int \ln x \, dx = x \ln x - \int x \cdot \frac{1}{x} \, dx = x \ln x - \int 1 \, dx = x \ln x - x + C$

title: Trigonometric Substitution
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} \, dx$
solution: Let $x = \sin \theta$, then $dx = \cos \theta \, d\theta$ and $\sqrt{1-x^2} = \cos \theta$.\n\n$\int \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^2}} \, dx = \int \frac{\cos \theta}{\cos \theta} \, d\theta = \int 1 \, d\theta = \theta + C = \arcsin x + C$

title: Partial Fractions
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{1}{x^2-1} \, dx$
hints: Factor the denominator and use partial fractions.

title: Powers of Trig Functions
description: Evaluate $\int \sin^2 x \, dx$
solution:
Using $\sin^2 x =  rac{1 - \cos 2x}{2}$:

$\int \sin^2 x \, dx = \int  rac{1 - \cos 2x}{2} \, dx =  rac{1}{2}\int (1 - \cos 2x) \, dx$

$=  rac{1}{2}\left(x -  rac{\sin 2x}{2}ight) + C =  rac{x}{2} -  rac{\sin 2x}{4} + C$

title: Advanced Trig Substitution
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{1}{x^2\sqrt{x^2+4}} \, dx$
solution:
Let $x = 2	an	heta$, then $dx = 2\sec^2	heta \, d	heta$ and $\sqrt{x^2+4} = 2\sec	heta$.

$\int  rac{1}{x^2\sqrt{x^2+4}} \, dx = \int  rac{1}{4	an^2	heta \cdot 2\sec	heta} \cdot 2\sec^2	heta \, d	heta$

$= \int  rac{\sec	heta}{4	an^2	heta} \, d	heta =  rac{1}{4}\int  rac{\cos	heta}{\sin^2	heta} \, d	heta$

Let $u = \sin	heta$: $=  rac{1}{4}\int u^{-2} \, du = - rac{1}{4u} + C = - rac{1}{4\sin	heta} + C$

Back-substitute: $\sin	heta =  rac{x}{\sqrt{x^2+4}}$, so answer is $- rac{\sqrt{x^2+4}}{4x} + C$

title: Repeated Integration by Parts
description: Evaluate $\int e^x \sin x \, dx$
hints: Use by parts twice, then solve for the integral algebraically.
solution:
Let $I = \int e^x \sin x \, dx$

First: $u = \sin x$, $dv = e^x \, dx$. Then $du = \cos x \, dx$, $v = e^x$.
$I = e^x \sin x - \int e^x \cos x \, dx$

Second: For $\int e^x \cos x \, dx$, let $u = \cos x$, $dv = e^x \, dx$. Then $du = -\sin x \, dx$, $v = e^x$.
$\int e^x \cos x \, dx = e^x \cos x + \int e^x \sin x \, dx = e^x \cos x + I$

Substitute back:
$I = e^x \sin x - (e^x \cos x + I)$
$I = e^x \sin x - e^x \cos x - I$
$2I = e^x(\sin x - \cos x)$
$I =  rac{e^x(\sin x - \cos x)}{2} + C$

title: Complex Partial Fractions
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{x+1}{x^2(x-1)} \, dx$

title: Completing the Square
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{1}{x^2+4x+8} \, dx$
hints: Complete the square in the denominator.
solution:
$x^2+4x+8 = (x^2+4x+4) + 4 = (x+2)^2 + 4$

Let $u = x+2$, then $du = dx$:

$\int  rac{1}{x^2+4x+8} \, dx = \int  rac{1}{u^2+4} \, du =  rac{1}{2}\arctan\left( rac{u}{2}ight) + C =  rac{1}{2}\arctan\left( rac{x+2}{2}ight) + C$

title: Trig Powers Product
description: Evaluate $\int \sin^3 x \cos^2 x \, dx$
hints: Use $\sin^2 x = 1 - \cos^2 x$ to convert to powers of $\cos x$, then substitute $u = \cos x$.
solution:
$\int \sin^3 x \cos^2 x \, dx = \int \sin^2 x \cos^2 x \sin x \, dx = \int (1-\cos^2 x)\cos^2 x \sin x \, dx$

Let $u = \cos x$, then $du = -\sin x \, dx$:

$= -\int (1-u^2)u^2 \, du = -\int (u^2 - u^4) \, du = -\left( rac{u^3}{3} -  rac{u^5}{5}ight) + C$

$= - rac{\cos^3 x}{3} +  rac{\cos^5 x}{5} + C$

title: Secant Powers
description: Evaluate $\int \sec^3 x \, dx$
hints: Use integration by parts with $u = \sec x$, $dv = \sec^2 x \, dx$.
solution:
Let $u = \sec x$, $dv = \sec^2 x \, dx$. Then $du = \sec x 	an x \, dx$, $v = 	an x$.

$I = \int \sec^3 x \, dx = \sec x 	an x - \int 	an x \cdot \sec x 	an x \, dx$
$= \sec x 	an x - \int \sec x 	an^2 x \, dx$
$= \sec x 	an x - \int \sec x(\sec^2 x - 1) \, dx$
$= \sec x 	an x - \int \sec^3 x \, dx + \int \sec x \, dx$
$I = \sec x 	an x - I + \ln|\sec x + 	an x|$
$2I = \sec x 	an x + \ln|\sec x + 	an x|$
$I =  rac{1}{2}[\sec x 	an x + \ln|\sec x + 	an x|] + C$

title: Challenge: Strategy Selection
description: Evaluate $\int \frac{x^3}{\sqrt{x^2+1}} \, dx$
hints: Try $u = x^2+1$ or use trig substitution.

title: Drill: Area Between Curves Formula
description: State the formula for the area between curves $y = f(x)$ and $y = g(x)$ from $a$ to $b$ where $f(x) \geq g(x)$.
hints: Integrate the difference of the functions.
solution: Area $= \int_a^b [f(x) - g(x)] \, dx$

title: Drill: Disk Method
description: State the disk method formula for volume when rotating $y = f(x)$ about the x-axis from $a$ to $b$.
hints: Volume uses $\pi r^2$ for circular cross-sections.
solution: $V = \int_a^b \pi [f(x)]^2 \, dx$

title: Drill: Arc Length
description: State the arc length formula for $y = f(x)$ from $a$ to $b$.
hints: Use the Pythagorean theorem on infinitesimal segments.
solution: $L = \int_a^b \sqrt{1 + [f'(x)]^2} \, dx$

title: Drill: Shell Method
description: State the shell method formula for rotating about the y-axis.
hints: Shells have circumference $2\pi r$ and height $h$.
solution: $V = \int_a^b 2\pi x f(x) \, dx$ where $x$ is the radius and $f(x)$ is the height

title: Area Between Curves
description: Find the area between $y = x^2$ and $y = x$ from $x = 0$ to $x = 1$.
hints: Determine which function is on top.

title: Volume by Disks
description: Find the volume when the region under $y = \sqrt{x}$ from $x = 0$ to $x = 4$ is rotated about the x-axis.
solution: $V = \int_0^4 \pi (\sqrt{x})^2 \, dx = \pi \int_0^4 x \, dx = \pi \left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^4 = \pi \cdot 8 = 8\pi$

title: Volume by Washers
description: Find the volume when the region between $y = x$ and $y = x^2$ from $x = 0$ to $x = 1$ is rotated about the x-axis.

title: Volume by Shells
description: Find the volume when the region under $y = x^2$ from $x = 0$ to $x = 2$ is rotated about the y-axis using shells.
solution: $V = \int_0^2 2\pi x \cdot x^2 \, dx = 2\pi \int_0^2 x^3 \, dx = 2\pi \left[\frac{x^4}{4}\right]_0^2$\n\n$= 2\pi \cdot 4 = 8\pi$

title: Arc Length of Line
description: Find the arc length of $y = 2x + 1$ from $x = 0$ to $x = 3$.

title: Arc Length of Parabola
description: Set up (but do not evaluate) the integral for the arc length of $y = x^2$ from $x = 0$ to $x = 1$.

title: Surface Area
description: Find the surface area when $y = \sqrt{x}$ from $x = 1$ to $x = 4$ is rotated about the x-axis.

title: Work - Spring Problem
description: A spring with spring constant $k = 20$ N/m is stretched from its natural length to 0.5 m beyond. Find the work done.

title: Work - Pumping Water
description: A cylindrical tank with radius 2 m and height 5 m is filled with water (density 1000 kg/mÂ³). Set up the integral to find the work required to pump all water to the top.
hints: Slice horizontally at height $y$. Each slice has volume $\pi(2)^2 dy$ and must be lifted $(5-y)$ meters.
solution:
Weight of slice at height $y$: $dW = ho g \cdot \pi r^2 \, dy = 1000 \cdot 9.8 \cdot 4\pi \, dy = 39200\pi \, dy$

Distance to lift: $5 - y$

Work: $W = \int_0^5 39200\pi (5-y) \, dy = 39200\pi \int_0^5 (5-y) \, dy$

$= 39200\pi \left[5y -  rac{y^2}{2}ight]_0^5 = 39200\pi(25 - 12.5) = 490000\pi$ J

title: Area Between Multiple Curves
description: Find the area enclosed by $y = x^2 - 4$ and $y = 4 - x^2$.

title: Volume with Variable Axis
description: Find the volume when the region between $y = x$ and $y = x^2$ is rotated about the line $y = 2$.
hints: Washer method: outer radius = $2 - x^2$, inner radius = $2 - x$.
solution:
For $x \in [0,1]$:

Outer radius: $R = 2 - x^2$
Inner radius: $r = 2 - x$

$V = \int_0^1 \pi[(2-x^2)^2 - (2-x)^2] \, dx$

$= \pi \int_0^1 [(4 - 4x^2 + x^4) - (4 - 4x + x^2)] \, dx$

$= \pi \int_0^1 (x^4 - 5x^2 + 4x) \, dx = \pi \left[ rac{x^5}{5} -  rac{5x^3}{3} + 2x^2ight]_0^1$

$= \pi\left( rac{1}{5} -  rac{5}{3} + 2ight) = \pi\left( rac{3 - 25 + 30}{15}ight) =  rac{8\pi}{15}$

title: Challenge: Shells vs Disks
description: Find the volume when the region bounded by $y = e^x$, $y = 0$, $x = 0$, and $x = 1$ is rotated about the y-axis using both methods.
hints: Shells: easier. Disks: requires solving for $x$ in terms of $y$.
solution:
Shell Method: radius = $x$, height = $e^x$

$V = \int_0^1 2\pi x e^x \, dx$

By parts ($u=x, dv=e^x dx$):
$= 2\pi[xe^x - e^x]_0^1 = 2\pi[(e - e) - (0 - 1)] = 2\pi$

Disk Method: $x = \ln y$, so $y \in [1, e]$

$V = \int_1^e \pi(\ln y)^2 \, dy$

By parts twice (omitted): this gives the same answer $2\pi$

title: Drill: Improper Integral Definition
description: What makes an integral "improper"?
solution: An integral is improper if: (1) one or both limits of integration are infinite, or (2) the integrand has an infinite discontinuity in the interval.

title: Drill: p-Test
description: For what values of $p$ does $\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x^p} \, dx$ converge?
solution: Converges if and only if $p > 1$.

title: Drill: Basic Convergence
description: Does $\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x} \, dx$ converge or diverge?
solution: Diverges (by p-test with $p = 1$).

title: Drill: Evaluating Improper Integrals
description: To evaluate $\int_1^\infty f(x) \, dx$, we compute the limit of what?
solution: $\lim_{t \to \infty} \int_1^t f(x) \, dx$

title: Evaluating Improper Integrals
description: Evaluate: $\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x^2} \, dx$
hints: Take the limit as upper bound approaches infinity.
solution: $\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x^2} \, dx = \lim_{t \to \infty} \int_1^t x^{-2} \, dx = \lim_{t \to \infty} \left[-\frac{1}{x}\right]_1^t$\n\n$= \lim_{t \to \infty} \left(-\frac{1}{t} + 1\right) = 0 + 1 = 1$

title: Exponential Improper Integral
description: Evaluate: $\int_0^\infty e^{-x} \, dx$
solution: $\int_0^\infty e^{-x} \, dx = \lim_{t \to \infty} \int_0^t e^{-x} \, dx = \lim_{t \to \infty} [-e^{-x}]_0^t$\n\n$= \lim_{t \to \infty} (-e^{-t} + 1) = 0 + 1 = 1$

title: Discontinuity at Endpoint
description: Evaluate: $\int_0^1 \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} \, dx$

title: Direct Comparison Test
description: Show that $\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x^2+1} \, dx$ converges using comparison.
solution: For $x \geq 1$: $x^2 + 1 > x^2$, so $\frac{1}{x^2+1} < \frac{1}{x^2}$\n\nSince $\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x^2} \, dx$ converges (p-test with $p=2>1$), and $0 \leq \frac{1}{x^2+1} \leq \frac{1}{x^2}$, by Direct Comparison Test, $\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x^2+1} \, dx$ converges.

title: Limit Comparison Test
description: Determine if $\int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2+1} \, dx$ converges using limit comparison.
solution:
For large $x$, $ rac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2+1} \approx  rac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2} =  rac{1}{x^{3/2}}$

Let $f(x) =  rac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2+1}$ and $g(x) =  rac{1}{x^{3/2}}$

$L = \lim_{x 	o \infty}  rac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \lim_{x 	o \infty}  rac{\sqrt{x} \cdot x^{3/2}}{x^2+1} = \lim_{x 	o \infty}  rac{x^2}{x^2+1} = 1$

Since $\int_1^\infty  rac{1}{x^{3/2}} \, dx$ converges ($p = 3/2 > 1$) and $L = 1 > 0$, by Limit Comparison Test, $\int_1^\infty  rac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2+1} \, dx$ converges.

title: Both Limits Infinite
description: Evaluate: $\int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{1}{1+x^2} \, dx$
solution: By symmetry: $\int_{-\infty}^\infty \frac{1}{1+x^2} \, dx = 2\int_0^\infty \frac{1}{1+x^2} \, dx$\n\n$= 2\lim_{t \to \infty} [\arctan x]_0^t = 2\lim_{t \to \infty} (\arctan t - 0) = 2 \cdot \frac{\pi}{2} = \pi$

title: Interior Discontinuity
description: Evaluate: $\int_0^3 \frac{1}{x-1} \, dx$
solution:
Discontinuity at $x = 1$, so:

$\int_0^3  rac{1}{x-1} \, dx = \lim_{t 	o 1^-} \int_0^t  rac{1}{x-1} \, dx + \lim_{s 	o 1^+} \int_s^3  rac{1}{x-1} \, dx$

$= \lim_{t 	o 1^-} [\ln|x-1|]_0^t + \lim_{s 	o 1^+} [\ln|x-1|]_s^3$

$= \lim_{t 	o 1^-} (\ln|t-1| - \ln 1) + \lim_{s 	o 1^+} (\ln 2 - \ln|s-1|)$

Both limits are $-\infty$, so the integral **diverges**.

title: Comparison with Polynomial
description: Determine if $\int_2^\infty \frac{x+1}{x^3-1} \, dx$ converges.
solution: For large $x$: $\frac{x+1}{x^3-1} \approx \frac{x}{x^3} = \frac{1}{x^2}$\n\nSince $\int_2^\infty \frac{1}{x^2} \, dx$ converges ($p=2>1$), and the behavior at infinity matches, by Limit Comparison Test, $\int_2^\infty \frac{x+1}{x^3-1} \, dx$ **converges**.

title: Gamma Function
description: Evaluate: $\int_0^\infty x e^{-x} \, dx$
solution:
Let $u = x$, $dv = e^{-x} \, dx$. Then $du = dx$, $v = -e^{-x}$.

$\int_0^\infty x e^{-x} \, dx = \lim_{t 	o \infty} \left[-xe^{-x}ight]_0^t + \int_0^\infty e^{-x} \, dx$

$= \lim_{t 	o \infty} (-te^{-t} + 0) + [-e^{-x}]_0^\infty$

$= 0 + (0 - (-1)) = 1$

title: Recognizing Divergence
description: Does $\int_1^\infty \frac{\ln x}{x} \, dx$ converge?
solution:
Let $u = \ln x$, then $du =  rac{1}{x} \, dx$. When $x = 1$, $u = 0$; as $x 	o \infty$, $u 	o \infty$.

$\int_1^\infty  rac{\ln x}{x} \, dx = \int_0^\infty u \, du = \lim_{t 	o \infty} \left[ rac{u^2}{2}ight]_0^t = \lim_{t 	o \infty}  rac{t^2}{2} = \infty$

The integral **diverges**.

title: Laplace Transform
description: Evaluate: $\int_0^\infty e^{-2x} \sin x \, dx$
solution:
Let $I = \int e^{-2x} \sin x \, dx$

First by parts: $u = \sin x$, $dv = e^{-2x} \, dx$
$I = - rac{1}{2}e^{-2x}\sin x +  rac{1}{2}\int e^{-2x}\cos x \, dx$

Second by parts on $\int e^{-2x}\cos x \, dx$: $u = \cos x$, $dv = e^{-2x} \, dx$
$\int e^{-2x}\cos x \, dx = - rac{1}{2}e^{-2x}\cos x -  rac{1}{2}I$

Substitute back:
$I = - rac{1}{2}e^{-2x}\sin x +  rac{1}{2}\left(- rac{1}{2}e^{-2x}\cos x -  rac{1}{2}Iight)$
$I = - rac{1}{2}e^{-2x}\sin x -  rac{1}{4}e^{-2x}\cos x -  rac{1}{4}I$
$ rac{5}{4}I = - rac{e^{-2x}}{4}(2\sin x + \cos x)$
$I = - rac{e^{-2x}(2\sin x + \cos x)}{5}$

Evaluate from 0 to $\infty$:
$\int_0^\infty e^{-2x} \sin x \, dx = \left[- rac{e^{-2x}(2\sin x + \cos x)}{5}ight]_0^\infty = 0 - \left(- rac{1}{5}ight) =  rac{1}{5}$

title: Challenge: Parameter Dependency
description: For what values of $a$ does $\int_0^1 \frac{1}{x^a} \, dx$ converge?
solution:
$\int_0^1  rac{1}{x^a} \, dx = \lim_{t 	o 0^+} \int_t^1 x^{-a} \, dx$

If $a 
eq 1$:
$= \lim_{t 	o 0^+} \left[ rac{x^{1-a}}{1-a}ight]_t^1 = \lim_{t 	o 0^+}  rac{1 - t^{1-a}}{1-a}$

This converges if $1-a > 0$, i.e., $a < 1$.

If $a = 1$: $\int_0^1  rac{1}{x} \, dx = \lim_{t 	o 0^+} [\ln x]_t^1 = \lim_{t 	o 0^+} (0 - \ln t) = \infty$, diverges.

**Answer**: Converges for $a < 1$.

title: Drill: Sequence Limit
description: Find $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n}$.
hints: As n grows, what happens to 1/n?
solution: $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n} = 0$

title: Drill: Geometric Series
description: What is the sum of $\sum_{n=0}^\infty r^n$ when $|r| < 1$?

title: Drill: Divergence Test
description: If $\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n \neq 0$, what can we conclude about $\sum a_n$?
solution: The series $\sum a_n$ diverges.

title: Drill: Ratio Test
description: In the Ratio Test, if $L < 1$, what do we conclude?
solution: The series converges absolutely.

title: Sequence Limits
description:
Find the following limits:

(a) $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n}{n+1}$

(b) $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^2}{2n^2+1}$
hints: Divide numerator and denominator by highest power of n.
solution: (a) $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n}{n+1} = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{1+1/n} = \frac{1}{1+0} = 1$\n\n(b) $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^2}{2n^2+1} = \lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{2+1/n^2} = \frac{1}{2}$

title: Geometric Series Sum
description: Find the sum: $\sum_{n=0}^\infty \left(\frac{1}{3}\right)^n$
hints: Use the geometric series formula with $r = 1/3$.
solution:
This is a geometric series with $a = 1$ and $r = 1/3$.

Since $|r| = 1/3 < 1$, it converges to:

$S =  rac{a}{1-r} =  rac{1}{1-1/3} =  rac{1}{2/3} =  rac{3}{2}$

title: Divergence Test
description: Determine if $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n}{n+1}$ converges or diverges.
solution:
$\lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{n}{n+1} = 1 
eq 0$

By the Divergence Test (nth Term Test), the series **diverges**.

title: Integral Test
description: Use the Integral Test to determine if $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^2}$ converges.
solution:
Let $f(x) =  rac{1}{x^2}$, which is positive, continuous, and decreasing for $x \geq 1$.

$\int_1^\infty  rac{1}{x^2} \, dx = \lim_{t 	o \infty} [- rac{1}{x}]_1^t = \lim_{t 	o \infty} (- rac{1}{t} + 1) = 1$

Since the integral converges, by the Integral Test, $\sum_{n=1}^\infty  rac{1}{n^2}$ **converges**.

title: Comparison Test
description: Determine if $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^n + n}$ converges.
solution:
For $n \geq 1$: $2^n + n \geq 2^n$, so $ rac{1}{2^n+n} \leq  rac{1}{2^n}$

$\sum_{n=1}^\infty  rac{1}{2^n}$ is a geometric series with $r = 1/2 < 1$, so it converges.

By the Direct Comparison Test, $\sum_{n=1}^\infty  rac{1}{2^n+n}$ **converges**.

title: Alternating Series Test
description: Determine if $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{n}$ converges.
solution:
The series alternates. Check: (1) $a_n =  rac{1}{n} > 0$, (2) $a_n$ is decreasing, (3) $\lim_{n 	o \infty} a_n = 0$.

All conditions satisfied, so by the Alternating Series Test, the series **converges**.

(This is the alternating harmonic series.)

title: Ratio Test
description: Use the Ratio Test to determine if $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n!}{n^n}$ converges.
solution:
$a_n =  rac{n!}{n^n}$, so:

$ rac{a_{n+1}}{a_n} =  rac{(n+1)!}{(n+1)^{n+1}} \cdot  rac{n^n}{n!} =  rac{(n+1)n^n}{(n+1)^{n+1}} =  rac{n^n}{(n+1)^n} = \left( rac{n}{n+1}ight)^n = \left( rac{1}{1+1/n}ight)^n$

$L = \lim_{n 	o \infty} \left( rac{1}{1+1/n}ight)^n =  rac{1}{e} < 1$

By the Ratio Test, the series **converges**.

title: Root Test
description: Use the Root Test on $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left(\frac{2n+1}{3n+2}\right)^n$.
solution:
$a_n = \left( rac{2n+1}{3n+2}ight)^n$

$\sqrt[n]{|a_n|} =  rac{2n+1}{3n+2}$

$L = \lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{2n+1}{3n+2} = \lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{2+1/n}{3+2/n} =  rac{2}{3} < 1$

By the Root Test, the series **converges**.

title: Absolute vs Conditional Convergence
description: Determine if $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{n}$ converges absolutely or conditionally.
solution:
We know $\sum_{n=1}^\infty  rac{(-1)^n}{n}$ converges (alternating harmonic series).

Check absolute convergence: $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left| rac{(-1)^n}{n}ight| = \sum_{n=1}^\infty  rac{1}{n}$

This is the harmonic series, which **diverges**.

Since the original series converges but the absolute series diverges, the series is **conditionally convergent**.

title: Limit Comparison Test
description: Use Limit Comparison to test $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n+1}{n^3+2}$.
solution:
For large $n$, $ rac{n+1}{n^3+2} \approx  rac{n}{n^3} =  rac{1}{n^2}$

Let $a_n =  rac{n+1}{n^3+2}$ and $b_n =  rac{1}{n^2}$:

$L = \lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{a_n}{b_n} = \lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{(n+1)n^2}{n^3+2} = \lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{n^3+n^2}{n^3+2} = 1$

Since $\sum  rac{1}{n^2}$ converges (p-series, $p=2>1$) and $L = 1$ (finite and positive), by Limit Comparison Test, $\sum_{n=1}^\infty  rac{n+1}{n^3+2}$ **converges**.

title: Telescoping Series
description: Find the sum: $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left(\frac{1}{n} - \frac{1}{n+1}\right)$
hints: Write out the first few partial sums.
solution:
Partial sums:
$S_1 =  rac{1}{1} -  rac{1}{2}$
$S_2 = \left( rac{1}{1} -  rac{1}{2}ight) + \left( rac{1}{2} -  rac{1}{3}ight) = 1 -  rac{1}{3}$
$S_3 = 1 -  rac{1}{4}$

General: $S_n = 1 -  rac{1}{n+1}$

$\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left( rac{1}{n} -  rac{1}{n+1}ight) = \lim_{n 	o \infty} S_n = \lim_{n 	o \infty} \left(1 -  rac{1}{n+1}ight) = 1$

title: Challenge: Multiple Tests
description: Determine if $\sum_{n=2}^\infty \frac{1}{n(\ln n)^2}$ converges.
hints: Use the Integral Test with $u = \ln x$.
solution:
Let $f(x) =  rac{1}{x(\ln x)^2}$ for $x \geq 2$. This is positive, continuous, and decreasing.

$\int_2^\infty  rac{1}{x(\ln x)^2} \, dx$

Let $u = \ln x$, then $du =  rac{1}{x} \, dx$. When $x = 2$, $u = \ln 2$; as $x 	o \infty$, $u 	o \infty$.

$= \int_{\ln 2}^\infty  rac{1}{u^2} \, du = \lim_{t 	o \infty} \left[- rac{1}{u}ight]_{\ln 2}^t = \lim_{t 	o \infty} \left(- rac{1}{t} +  rac{1}{\ln 2}ight) =  rac{1}{\ln 2}$

Since the integral converges, by the Integral Test, $\sum_{n=2}^\infty  rac{1}{n(\ln n)^2}$ **converges**.

title: Drill: Power Series Form
description: Write the general form of a power series centered at $c$.
solution: $\sum_{n=0}^\infty a_n(x-c)^n$

title: Drill: Maclaurin vs Taylor
description: What is the difference between a Maclaurin series and a Taylor series?
solution: A Maclaurin series is a Taylor series centered at $a = 0$.

title: Drill: Taylor Series Formula
description: Write the formula for the Taylor series of $f(x)$ centered at $a$.
solution: $\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!}(x-a)^n$

title: Drill: Radius of Convergence
description: What does the radius of convergence tell us?
solution: The radius $R$ gives the interval $(c-R, c+R)$ where the power series converges.

title: Radius of Convergence
description: Find the radius of convergence for $\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n!}$.
solution:
$a_n =  rac{1}{n!}$

$\lim_{n 	o \infty} \left| rac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}ight| = \lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{n!}{(n+1)!} = \lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{1}{n+1} = 0$

$L|x| = 0 < 1$ for all $x$, so the radius of convergence is $R = \infty$.

title: Interval of Convergence
description: Find the interval of convergence for $\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n}$.
hints: Use Ratio Test, then check endpoints.
solution:
Ratio Test:
$L = \lim_{n 	o \infty} \left| rac{a_{n+1}x^{n+1}}{a_n x^n}ight| = \lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{n}{n+1}|x| = |x|$

Converges when $|x| < 1$, so $R = 1$.

Check endpoints:
At $x = 1$: $\sum  rac{1}{n}$ diverges (harmonic series).
At $x = -1$: $\sum  rac{(-1)^n}{n}$ converges (alternating harmonic).

**Interval of convergence**: $[-1, 1)$

title: Geometric Series as Power Series
description: Express $\frac{1}{1-x}$ as a power series and state its radius of convergence.
solution: $\frac{1}{1-x} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n$ for $|x| < 1$\n\n**Radius of convergence**: $R = 1$

title: Maclaurin Series for e^x
description: Derive the first 4 terms of the Maclaurin series for $f(x) = e^x$.

title: Maclaurin Series for sin(x)
description: Write the Maclaurin series for $\sin x$.
hints: Derivatives of sine cycle through sine and cosine.
solution:
$f(x) = \sin x, f(0) = 0$
$f'(x) = \cos x, f'(0) = 1$
$f''(x) = -\sin x, f''(0) = 0$
$f'''(x) = -\cos x, f'''(0) = -1$
$f^{(4)}(x) = \sin x, f^{(4)}(0) = 0$

Pattern: only odd powers, alternating signs

$\sin x = \sum_{n=0}^\infty  rac{(-1)^n x^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!} = x -  rac{x^3}{3!} +  rac{x^5}{5!} -  rac{x^7}{7!} + \cdots$

title: Maclaurin Series for cos(x)
description: Write the Maclaurin series for $\cos x$.
hints: Similar to sine, but starts differently.
solution:
$f(x) = \cos x, f(0) = 1$
$f'(x) = -\sin x, f'(0) = 0$
$f''(x) = -\cos x, f''(0) = -1$
$f'''(x) = \sin x, f'''(0) = 0$

Pattern: only even powers, alternating signs

$\cos x = \sum_{n=0}^\infty  rac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{(2n)!} = 1 -  rac{x^2}{2!} +  rac{x^4}{4!} -  rac{x^6}{6!} + \cdots$

title: Taylor Polynomial Approximation
description: Find the 3rd degree Taylor polynomial for $f(x) = \ln x$ centered at $a = 1$.

title: Operations on Power Series
description: Find the power series for $f(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}$ by modifying the geometric series.

title: Integration of Power Series
description: Find the power series for $\arctan x$ by integrating the series for $\frac{1}{1+x^2}$.
solution:
From previous: $ rac{1}{1+x^2} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-1)^n x^{2n}$

Integrate term by term:
$\arctan x = \int \sum_{n=0}^\infty (-1)^n x^{2n} \, dx = \sum_{n=0}^\infty  rac{(-1)^n x^{2n+1}}{2n+1} + C$

Using $\arctan(0) = 0$, we have $C = 0$.

$\arctan x = \sum_{n=0}^\infty  rac{(-1)^n x^{2n+1}}{2n+1} = x -  rac{x^3}{3} +  rac{x^5}{5} -  rac{x^7}{7} + \cdots$

title: Differentiation of Power Series
description: Find the power series for $\cos x$ by differentiating the series for $\sin x$.
hints: Differentiate $\sin x = \sum \frac{(-1)^n x^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!}$ term by term.
solution:
$\sin x = \sum_{n=0}^\infty  rac{(-1)^n x^{2n+1}}{(2n+1)!}$

Differentiate:
$\cos x =  rac{d}{dx}[\sin x] = \sum_{n=0}^\infty  rac{(-1)^n (2n+1)x^{2n}}{(2n+1)!} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty  rac{(-1)^n x^{2n}}{(2n)!}$

$= 1 -  rac{x^2}{2!} +  rac{x^4}{4!} - \cdots$

title: Error Estimation
description: Estimate $e^{0.5}$ using the 3rd degree Taylor polynomial and bound the error.

title: Challenge: Binomial Series
description: Find the first 4 terms of the Maclaurin series for $f(x) = \sqrt{1+x}$.
hints: Use the binomial series $(1+x)^{1/2}$ or compute derivatives.
